questions.text: A young man presented with pain abdomen, diarrhoea, and fever gradually increasing in a step ladder pattern over the past 2 weeks. A Widal test confirmed the diagnosis and he was admitted. A few days later, he developed intestinal perforation and was taken up for exploratory laparotomy. Which of the following findings would you see in this patient?
questions.solution:
Typhoid causes longitudinal ulcers.

Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella typhi. It presents with step-ladder fever and abdominal pain after an incubation period of 10–20 days. Over the next week, the patient can develop:

  • Distension
  • Diarrhoea
  • Splenomegaly
  • Characteristic rose spots on the abdomen caused by a vasculitis

Surgical complications of typhoid are:

  • Paralytic ileus
  • Intestinal haemorrhage
  • Free ileal perforation (characteristically occurs during the third week of the illness)
  • Cholecystitis
  • Longitudinal ulcers (usually situated in the distal ileum)

Diagnosis of typhoid is confirmed by culture of blood or stool.

Treatment is by antibiotics, usually chloramphenicol. 

Perforation requires surgery to wash out and close the ulcer. Intestinal resection is usually avoided. In unstable patients, with evidence of septic shock, the bowel should be exteriorized and the perforation closed after recovery. Paratyphoid infection also resembles typhoid fever and is treated in a similar manner. 

Note: Transverse ulcers with stricture formation are seen in tuberculosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest sign in Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Aphthous ulcers, surrounded by a rim of erythematous mucosa, are the earliest lesions seen in a patient with Crohn's disease during endoscopy.

Crohn's colitis usually spares the rectum and is most severe in the ileocaecal region.

  • In early Crohn's disease, small, punched-out aphthous ulcers are often seen (the result of submucosal lymphoid follicle expansion).
  • In moderate disease, the aphthous ulcers coalesce into larger ulcers, which may take on the appearance of a star (stellate ulcers).
  • As disease severity increases, submucosal edema and injury can result in cobblestoning of the mucosa (option A) and eventually the formation of serpiginous ulcers, which are typical findings in Crohn's disease. 

Thorn-like extraluminal projections in barium studies are known as rose-thorn appearance, and are a typical sign of Crohn's disease. They represent deep penetrating linear ulcers or fissurings typically seen within stenosed terminal ileum with a thickened wall. (Options C and D)

Related Pearl: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)

 

  Crohn's disease Ulcerative colitis
Age of onset  2nd-4th decades & 7th-9th decades 2nd-4th decades & 7th-9th decades 
Most common presentation Ileocolitis with rectal sparing Proctitis (rectum)
Protective factors  None 

Smoking 

Appendicectomy
Risk factors

OCP

Smoking

Antibiotic during first year of life 

α-Methyldopa

Antibiotic during first year of life

Skip lesions

Cobblestone appearance

Creeping fat

Longitudinal ulcers

Mucosal and superficial submucosal involvement 

Continuous involvement

Pseudopolyps

Collar button ulcers
Earliest finding Aphthous ulcer Erythematous mucosa with a fine granular surface
Microscopic findings 

Deep, knife-like ulcers

Granulomas

Pyloric metaplasia

Complications

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient who had sustained burn injuries over bilateral lower limbs 1 year ago, has an ulcer over his left leg that has not healed despite regular treatment, and malignant transformation is suspected. Which of the following types of edge would most likely be seen in this ulcer?
questions.solution:
A chronic non-healing ulcer with malignant transformation would have everted edges, as shown in image E.

The majority of wounds that have not healed in 3 months are considered chronic and are prone to malignant changes. Malignant wounds are differentiated clinically from non-malignant wounds by the presence of overturned edges. Biopsy of the wound edges should be performed to rule out malignancy. Malignant transformation can occur in any long-standing wound. The image shows a Marjolin's ulcer with everted edges. It is squamous cell carcinoma that develops on a long-standing burn.

The edge of an ulcer is the region between the margin and the floor of the ulcer. Five types of ulcer edges and the conditions they are associated with are described as follows:

questions.text: In patients with which of the following conditions, would the following procedure be contraindicated?
questions.solution:
The given image is depictive of Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) or Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT). Malignancy developing from a wound (like Marjolin’s ulcer) is a contraindication for NPWT. 

Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) or NPWT is a therapeutic technique using a vacuum dressing to promote healing in acute and chronic wounds. The principle of VAC is an intermittent negative pressure of ~125 mmHg hastens debridement and formation of granulation tissue in chronic wounds. The negative pressure removes the interstitial fluid to decrease the edema and also increases the blood flow. The principle is used in treating diabetic foot ulcers as well as stage III and IV pressure ulcers. It is useful for the same reason in traumatic wounds, flaps and grafts, and dehisced incisions.

Some of the contraindications of NPWT are:

  • Exposed vasculature or organ surfaces has an increased risk of leakage of blood following tissue erosion.
  • Non-enteric and unexplored fistulae can lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.
  • Necrotic tissue or eschar in the wound bed can exacerbate the non healing and necrosis. 
  • Inadequate debridement of devitalized soft tissue or bone increases the risk of infection.
  • The presence of an underlying malignancy due to its ability to propagate and metastasize.
  • Active osteomyelitis.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions would you consider as possible differentials in a patient presenting with a painless genital ulcer?
  1. Syphilis
  2. Granuloma inguinale
  3. Lymphogranuloma venerum
  4. Genital herpes
  5. Chancroid
questions.solution:
Painless genital ulcers are seen in syphilis, granuloma inguinale, and lymphogranuloma venerum.

Genital herpes is typically associated with painful vesicles and chancroid is characterized by painful genital ulcers.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

 1-12 weeks 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

 Azithromycin/ceftriaxone  Doxycycline

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of mass descending per vaginum for the past 6 months. On examination, grade 3 uterovaginal prolapse and a decubitus ulcer are observed. What causes this ulcer?
questions.solution:
Decubitus ulcer seen in uterine prolapse is due to venous congestion and local circulatory changes.

Decubitus ulcer refers to the ulceration of prolapsed tissue which occurs due to the chronic dependent position causing venous congestion and stasis. It has a clean edge and usually heals well with prolapse reduction and daily packing with glycerine (hygroscopic agent) and acriflavine (antiseptic). It is a benign and non-infectious disease and does not require further investigation such as biopsy or culture.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with post-operative wounds?
questions.solution:
Meleney's ulcer is associated with post-operative wounds.

Meleney's ulcer, also known as post-operative synergistic bacterial gangrene is a polymicrobial infection caused by a synergistic interaction between microaerophilic nonhemolytic Streptococcus and hemolytic aerobic Staphylococcus aureus. It occurs more commonly in immunocompromised patients and in infected cases such as perforations and abscesses or where there is a pre-existing ulcer such as ulcerative colitis. The ulcer begins from the margins of the wound and spreads to the subcutaneous tissue with foul-smelling discharge and purulent granulation tissue, associated with pain and toxaemia with high morbidity. The ulcer is described to have a purple rim which is surrounded by a reddish erythematous zone. 

Patients require early and aggressive critical care treatment. Hyperbaric oxygen has been shown to reduce mortality in patients with Meleney's gangrene and therefore plays a significant role in the management of this condition.

 

Option A: Hunner's ulcers are seen in a subset of patients with interstitial cystitis. These are areas of inflammation on the bladder wall. 

The image below shows a cystoscopic image of a Hunner's ulcer.

 

Option B: Buruli ulcer is caused by infection with Mycobacterium ulcerans, which produces a toxin called mycolactone. This is a chronic, debilitating, necrotizing disease of the skin and soft tissue which is characterized by the formation of ulcers that progressively enlarge over time if left untreated.

The image below shows a Buruli ulcer. 

 

Option D: Marjolin's ulcer is a rare and aggressive form of squamous cell carcinoma that grows from burns, scars, or poorly healing wounds. 

The image below shows a Marjolin's ulcer in a burn scar.

questions.text: A patient with an ulcer shown in the image below is admitted to the general surgery ward. A history of which of the following would you be likely to elicit in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows an ulcer with an undermined edge, which is seen in tuberculosis and could be associated with a preceding history of chronic cough and weight loss. 

Other options:

Option A: Unprotected sexual intercourse may be a significant history pointing towards syphilis which causes an ulcer with punched-out edges and wash-leather slough.

Option B: Exposure to UV radiation suggests the development of skin cancer. Squamous cell carcinoma has everted edges and basal cell carcinoma has rolled-out edges.

Option D: Diabetes mellitus causes neuropathic/trophic ulcer with punched-out edges.

questions.text:
Match the ulcers with the relevant investigations to be performed in the patient.
  1. Marjolin's ulcer                         
  2. Martorell's ulcer                         
  3. Curling's ulcer                          
  4. Cushing's ulcer                          
  5. Bairnsdale ulcer                       
  1.  Fluid intake/output
  2. Acid-fast staining
  3. BP measurement
  4. ICP monitoring
  5. Skin biopsy
questions.solution:
Ulcer Underlying pathology Relevant investigation
1. Marjolin's ulcer Squamous cell carcinoma Skin biopsy
2. Martorell's ulcer Hypertension BP measurement
3. Curling's ulcer Burns Fluid intake/output
4. Cushing's ulcer Raised intra-cranial pressure ICP monitoring
5. Bairnsdale ulcer Mycobacterial infection Acid-fast staining

questions.text: Identify the given condition.
questions.solution:
The given picture showing an ulcer with punched-out edges over a pressure point is most likely that of a trophic ulcer/neuropathic ulcer.

A neuropathic ulcer is one that occurs as a result of peripheral neuropathy. In peripheral neuropathy, lack of sensation over the pressure points leads to cumulative microtrauma, minor wounds, or cuts that remain unnoticed but eventually develop into ulcers.

Features of a neuropathic ulcer include

  • Painless ulcer
  • Punched out ulcer with regular margins
  • Often located on the plantar surface of the foot
  • Ulcer margins show the presence of calluses 
  Ischemic/Arterial Ulcer Venous Ulcer Neuropathic Ulcer  Tuberculous Ulcer   
Underlying condition

Peripheral vascular disease- mainly atherosclerosis, thromboangiitis obliterans, cervical rib, Raynaud's phenomenon

 Varicose veins, previous deep vein thrombosis Diabetes, peripheral neuropathy Tuberculosis lymph nodes, cold abscess from bone and joint tuberculosis
Location Toes, feet, legs, or even upper limb digits Lower limb, commonly on the medial side of the ankle, never above the middle third of the leg The plantar surface of the foot, toes Neck, axilla, and groin
Characteristics

Deep, penetrates the deep fascia exposing the tendons, muscles, and underlying bone.

The ulcer is painful, tender, and hyperaesthetic. 

 Vertically oval, painless, the floor may have pale to no granulation tissue, induration, and tenderness at the base. Punched-out with regular calloused margins. 

Edges are thin, reddish blue, undermined; pale granulation tissue, scanty discharge on the floor, and slight induration at the base
Other features Features of ischemia in adjacent areas, like pallor, dry skin, brittle nails, loss of hair Inguinal lymph nodes are enlarged, usually the vertical group, and the ulcer is recurrent; forms again after healing Dry, cracked, insensate Regional lymph nodes are enlarged, non-tender, matted

 

Option A) The following is an image of a venous ulcer

Option B) The following is an image of a malignant ulcer (squamous cell carcinoma)

Option C) The following is an image of an arterial ulcer

questions.text: A 50 year old male patient with a chronic ulcer over the lower limb has been advised to undergo a biopsy for further evaluation. From which part of the ulcer would the specimen be taken?
questions.solution:
Biopsy of an ulcer is taken from the edge as it contains multiplying cells. The floor is not chosen as it may be inadequate due to to the presence of necrotic tissue.

An ulcer is defined as a break in the continuity of the epithelium or mucous membrane with molecular death.

Classically an ulcer is described to have four parts which are: 

  • The margin is defined as the junction between the normal epithelium and the ulcer.
  • The edge is defined as the part between the margin and the floor.
  • The floor is defined as the exposed surface of the ulcer. It is better seen than felt, and may contain granulation tissue, discharge or slough. Trophic ulcers have bone as the floor due to their depth.
  • The base is defined as the structure on which the ulcer rests, eg, bone or soft tissue. It is better felt than seen.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old baby was brought with complaints of pink morbilliform rashes on the trunk as shown below. The child had a history of high fever for 3 days following which these rashes appeared. On oral examination, ulcers are present at the uvulopalatoglossal junction. Which of the following herpes viruses is most likely to be implicated in the pathogenesis of this disease?

HHV- Human herpesvirus
questions.solution:
The history of fever and ulcers at the uvulopalatoglossal junction (Nagayama spots) along with the image showing pink morbilliform rashes on the trunk of an infant makes the likely diagnosis roseola infantum. It is caused by a human Herpesvirus (HHV)- 6B, and 7.

Roseola infantum is also called as sixth disease or exanthema subitum. HHV-6B is responsible for the majority of cases of roseola infantum and only a small percentage of children with roseola have a primary infection with HHV-7.

Primary HHV-6B infection peaks between the ages of 6 and 9 months.

Clinical features include:

  • Prodrome of high-grade fever
  • Non-pruritic, morbilliform rash, which appears as the fever comes down.
  • Leucopenia and relative lymphocytosis
  • Nagayama spots: ulcers at uvulo-palatoglossal junction

Diagnosis includes polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for detecting the viral DNA.

This is a self-limiting disease and treatment is done as supportive care in the form of maintaining hydration and using antipyretics if the child has a fever. 

Official name Common name Pathophysiology
HHV-1 Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) Oral and/ or genital herpes (Mainly orofacial)
HHV-2 Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) Oral and/ or genital herpes (Mainly genital)
HHV-3 Varicella zoster virus (VZV) Chickenpox and shingles
HHV-4 Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) Infectious mononucleosis, Burkitt's lymphoma, Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disease, Nasopharyngeal carcinoma, CNS lymphoma in AIDS patients, and HIV-associated hairy leukoplakia
HHV-5 Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Infectious mononucleosis-like syndrome
HHV-6

Human Bcell lymphotropic virus

 Roseola infantum or exanthema subitum (The majority of the cases are caused by HHV-6)
HHV-7

RK virus

 Roseola infantum or exanthema subitum
HHV-8 Human herpesvirus 8 Kaposi's sarcoma, primary effusion lymphoma, multicentric Castleman's disease (MCD)

 

Related Pearl: Skin rashes: 1st to 6th diseases

1st disease

Measles

2nd disease

Scarlet fever

3rd disease

Rubella

4th disease

Duke’s disease

5th disease

Erythema infectiosum

6th disease

Roseola infantum

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

questions.text: A patient who had a history of an injury to the index finger a week ago presented to the OPD with the following finding of healthy appearing tissue growing beyond the margin of the ulcer. Which of the following might predispose to the finding shown?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and clinical findings are suggestive of exuberant granulation tissue or proud flesh.

Formation of exuberant granulation tissue may occur as a  deviation from normal wound healing where excessive amounts of granulation tissue protrude above the level of the surrounding skin and blocks re-epithelialization. It may be associated with the presence of a retained foreign body within the ulcer bed or underlying sinus cavity. Although it represents healthy tissue, the wound should be debrided and the granulation tissue should be excised using a Volkmann's scoop or by surgical cautery before it is allowed to heal with continuity of the epithelium.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient who has accompanied her grandmother for a check-up, asks you about ulcers she has developed in the oral mucosa. She has no other systemic symptoms and has no family history of chronic medical illness. What is the ideal next step?

choices.text: Rule out accidental bite or use of dentures/braces
Send blood for ESR and CRP
Reassure the patient that it is self-limiting

questions.solution:
Oral mucosal ulcers may be traumatic due to accidental biting, or the presence of dentures and braces hence the ideal next step would be to rule out the patient's use of such oral appliances.

Traumatic ulcers usually heal by simply removing the irritant without any other intervention and should be considered the possible diagnosis before investigating oral ulcers as aphthous ulcers.

Aphthous ulcers are painful, recurrent, and non-contagious oral lesions. They are well-circumscribed, ulcerative lesions with a white necrotic base surrounded by a red halo. They heal in 10–14 days without scarring. Their aetiology is unclear but they are associated with systemic illnesses such as inflammatory bowel disease, gluten-sensitive enteropathy and Behcet's disease and hence the presence of a positive family history or other suggestive symptoms or sings may warrant the need for further investigation once common causes like traumatic ulcers are ruled out.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of the lesion shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image showing a punched-out ulcer with regular margins located on the plantar surface of the foot points to the diagnosis of a neuropathic ulcer.

In peripheral neuropathy, lack of sensation over the pressure points leads to cumulative microtrauma, minor wounds, or cuts that go unnoticed eventually developing into ulcers.

Type of Ulcer Ischaemic/Arterial Venous Neuropathic Tuberculous  
Underlying condition

Peripheral vascular disease mainly atherosclerosis, thromboangitis obliterans, and Raynaud's phenomenon

 Varicose veins, previous deep vein thrombosis Diabetes, peripheral neuropathy Tuberculosis lymph nodes, cold abscess from bone and joint tuberculosis
Location Toes, feet, legs, or even upper limb digits Lower limb, commonly on the medial side of the ankle, never above the middle third of the leg The plantar surface of the foot and toes Neck, axilla, and groin
Characteristics

Deep, penetrates the deep fascia exposing the tendons, muscles, and underlying bone. The ulcer is painful, tender, and hyperaesthetic. 

 Vertically oval, and painless. The floor may have pale to no granulation tissue, induration, and tenderness at the base. Punched-out with regular calloused margins. 

Edges are thin, reddish blue, and undermined. Pale granulation tissue, scanty discharge on the floor, and slight induration at the base
Other features Features of ischemia in adjacent areas, like pallor, dry skin, brittle nails, loss of hair Inguinal lymph nodes are enlarged usually the vertical group. The ulcer is recurrent. Dry, cracked, insensate Regional lymph nodes are enlarged, non-tender, and matted

 

The following image depicts a venous ulcer. 

The following image depicts a tuberculous ulcer. 

The image below shows an arterial ulcer.

questions.text: A 20-year-old Nigerian tourist presents with the following painless lesion. He had noticed a hard nodule over the same area two weeks ago in his home country, prior to coming to India. As he had no pain, he did not pay attention to the progression of the ulcer. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is that of a Buruli ulcer, which is caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans.

It is the third most common mycobacterial skin infection in immunocompetent people. It is endemic to Africa and Australia, where it affects children and elderly people. It starts as a nodule or papule which progresses further to form an extensive, necrotic ulcer, exposing muscle and tendon. Most lesions occur on the lower extremities. Healing is slow.

questions.text: Collar button ulcer is a feature of _______
questions.solution:
Collar button ulcer is a feature of deep lesions in ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: In the examination of an ulcer, which of the following is best assessed by palpation?
questions.solution:
The base of an ulcer is better felt than seen and hence should be assessed by palpation.

An ulcer is defined as a break in the continuity of the epithelium or mucous membrane with molecular death. Classically an ulcer is described to have four parts which are: margin, edge, floor and base.

 

The margin is defined as the junction between the normal epithelium and the ulcer.

The edge is defined as the part between the margin and the floor. Five types of ulcer edges are commonly described as follows:

The floor is defined as the exposed surface of the ulcer. It is better seen than felt, and may contain granulation tissue, discharge or slough. Trophic ulcers have bone as the floor due to their depth.

The base is defined as the structure on which the ulcer rests, eg, bone or soft tissue. It is better felt than seen.

questions.text: A patient being evaluated for epigastric pain undergoes upper GI endoscopy which reveals multiple esophageal ulcers as shown in the image below. The most likely cause of these ulcers is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple punched out ulcers, characteristic of Herpes simplex (HSV) esophagitis. 

HSV esophagitis commonly occurs in immunocompromised patients. For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer. The following microscopic findings are noted:

  • Ballooning degeneration
  • Ground-glass changes in nuclei
  • Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

 

Conditions Endoscopic findings
Infectious esophagitis Diffuse and involve the proximal esophagus  
HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers
Peptic esophagitis Solitary and distal  
Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus
Candida esophagitis White friable plaques, in advance form - adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes.

 

The image below shows the lesions of CMV esophagitis.

The image below shows the lesions of candida esophagitis.

The image below shows feline esophagus in eosinophilic esophagitis.

The image below shows the erosive lesion of pill esophagitis.

The image below shows the lesions of HSV esophagitis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents with a history of injury to the eye caused while climbing a tree 5 days ago; the injury has caused pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. Slit-lamp examination reveals a lesion as shown below. Which of the following is a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image of an ulcer with irregular feathery margins are suggestive of a fungal corneal ulcer. Satellite lesions are a feature of fungal ulcers.

A fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter. Signs are more pronounced than symptoms. The corneal ulcer appears dry.

Causative organisms:

  • Aspergillus
  • Fusarium
  • Candida albicans

Signs of a fungal ulcer:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.
  • An immune ring (Wesseley ring) may be seen around the ulcer due to the deposition of the immune complexes.
  • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, and immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.

Treatment:

  • Topical drugs: These include topical natamycin, voriconazole, or amphotericin B drops, which are effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium. Nystatin is effective against Candida.
  • Systemic drugs: Severe ulcers with hypopyon, perforation, or suspected endophthalmitis might warrant the use of oral antifungal agents such as ketoconazole or voriconazole.

Other options :

Option A: Reverse hypopyon is the collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber. Here, emulsified silicone bubbles are coalesced and seen in the upper part of the anterior chamber (AC). 

Option B: Dendritic ulcer is seen in epithelial keratitis caused by the herpes simplex virus. An image of a dendritic ulcer with fluorescein dye is shown below.

Option C: Ring abscess is seen in helminthic keratitis, especially that caused by Acanthamoeba. Gradual enlargement and coalescence of infiltrates occur, leading to the formation of an abscess.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis
